question: Will the New York Times use the phrase "constitutional crisis" in its U.S. section before April 1, 2025?
description: The most recent usage of the phrase was on January 5, 2025, in this article: [‘A Day of Love’: How Trump Inverted the Violent History of Jan. 6](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/05/us/politics/january-6-capitol-riot-trump.html?searchResultPosition=1)
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**The New York Times’ Obsession with President Trump**
The New York Times has continued its attacks on President Trump since his election on November 5, 2024, and inauguration on January 20, 2025. The Times has devoted multiple pages to vicious and personal attacks on Trump, calling him a liar, a fraudster, and lawless, and claiming that he seeks to destroy democracy and cause a constitutional crisis. The Times has also attacked Trump's relationship with Elon Musk, saying that Musk is a 'co-president' and that Trump seeks to transform the presidency and make it powerful. The Times has also criticized Trump's handling of the ceasefire agreement with Hamas, saying that he did not keep his word and that Hamas called his bluff. Additionally, the Times has published a full-page ad from over 100 Rabbis, nearly all female, who oppose Trump's call for the removal of all Palestinians from Gaza, calling it 'ethnic cleansing'. The article concludes that the Times' attacks on Trump only strengthen his devotion to his followers and that the Times' strategy of driving a wedge between Trump and Musk is a sound one, knowing Trump's ego.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 05:53 AM
Source:[timesofisrael.com](https://blogs.timesofisrael.com/the-new-york-times-obsession-with-president-trump/)

**Period for Filing Claims for NYC ICE Settlement Now Open**
The period for filing claims for a settlement payment as part of a collective lawsuit against the City of New York is now open and will run until May 15, 2025. The lawsuit, Onadia v. City of New York, was settled for up to $92.5 million and covers people who were illegally detained by the New York City Department of Correction (NYC) solely due to immigration detention requests from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) between April 1, 1997, and December 21, 2012. Over 20,000 people who were detained beyond their scheduled release dates may be eligible for a payment of $10,000 or more. The settlement allows people from Mexico, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, Jamaica, Ecuador, Cuba, Colombia, Trinidad and Tobago, Honduras, and Guyana to file claims, regardless of their current residence in the United States. Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, a partner at Emery Celli Brinckerhoff Abady Ward & Maazel LLP, said, 'Our Constitution protects all human beings within the United States against detention without probable cause, regardless of their immigration status. This case teaches that those protections must be respected and that those who choose to ignore the Constitution will be held responsible.' Debra L. Greenberger, a partner at Emery Celli Brinckerhoff Abady Ward & Maazel LLP, added, 'We urge the media, community organizations, and individuals to share this information with anyone they know who may fit the description of a class member, so they can receive a settlement payment. The claims process is simple and can provide eligible class members with $10,000 or more.'
Original language: es
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:25 PM
Source:[PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/periodo-de-reclamaciones-ahora-abierto-para-personas-inmigrantes-de-mexico-y-otros-paises-que-fueron-ilegalmente-detenidas-en-carceles-de-nyc-por-ice-como-parte-de-un-acuerdo-de-demanda-colectiva-de-92-5-millones-de-dolares-contra-la-ciudad-871755996.html)

**Editorial Roundup: United States**
Recent editorials from The Washington Post, The New York Times, and The Wall Street Journal discuss the challenges facing the US under the Trump administration. The Washington Post argues that Trump's tariffs will not close the trade deficit, and that the trade deficit is a natural result of a country's current account deficit being financed by the rest of the world. The New York Times warns that Trump's actions are pushing the country towards a constitutional crisis, as he expands his executive authority and disregards the rule of law. The Wall Street Journal criticizes Trump's approach to peace talks in Ukraine, saying that it is a slap to NATO allies and that Europe needs to take responsibility for its own security. The Guardian argues that Ukraine should be included in deciding its own future, and that Trump's surrender to Russian aggression is a shock to Ukraine and its European allies.

**Quoting Napoleon, Trump Openly Declares He’s Above the Law**
President Donald Trump has openly declared that he is above the law, citing a quote from Napoleon Bonaparte that 'he who saves his country does not violate any law.' This statement has sparked fears of a constitutional crisis, with New York Times columnist Jamelle Bouie calling it 'the single most un-American and anti-constitutional statement ever uttered by an American president.' Trump's administration has been aggressively dismantling federal agencies and disregarding court orders, with some officials actively defying rulings from federal courts. This is reminiscent of the shameful period in U.S. history when Southern governors refused to integrate their schools after the Supreme Court ruled against segregation. Law professor Frank Bowman warns that if Trump successfully defies the courts, the only remaining obstacle to dictatorship will be public revulsion and national popular protest.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 06:01 AM
Source:[alaska-native-news.com](https://alaska-native-news.com/quoting-napoleon-trump-openly-declares-hes-above-the-law/77592/)

**MAS calls for opposition unity to face constitutional reform and April elections in Venezuela**
The Venezuelan party Movimiento al Socialismo (MAS) has called for unity among the opposition to face the constitutional reform promoted by Nicolás Maduro and to decide whether to participate in the April 27 legislative and regional elections, which have been rejected by the main anti-Chavista coalition, the Plataforma Unitaria Democrática (PUD). 'Is a national constitutional reform necessary when the country is immersed in a social, economic, and political crisis?', asked María Verdeal, the national vice-president of MAS, in a statement, referring to the situation after Maduro's re-election, proclaimed by the electoral body -controlled by Chavismo- after the July 2024 presidential elections, which PUD considers 'fraudulent'. Verdeal urged the 'democratic leadership' to take 'firm steps' to 'achieve unity' and design a 'solid strategy' that -she assured- 'would prevent' Maduro 'from playing solo' and, according to her, 'impose a constitutional reform unilaterally that could destroy the concept of the State'. She warned that it is not public knowledge whether the reform project 'will be total or partial', while affirming that these changes are 'in the hands of a unilateral commission', designated by Maduro. The commission has 90 days to elaborate a definitive project of reform. On the April elections, Verdeal expressed her concern because the phases of the schedule for that vote are developed 'in parallel to this constitutional reform, which -she considered- must be submitted to a referendum for its approval'. 'The worst is that, amidst all this entanglement, the opposition is divided between participating or abstaining, while those in power advance significantly to establish a project for the country unilaterally', she indicated. The opposition leader assured that the MAS 'fears a paralysis or division of the democratic sectors of the country', and anticipated that the party will decide 'soon' whether to participate in those elections. 
Original language: es
Publish date: February 18, 2025 01:55 AM
Source:[espanol.news.yahoo.com](https://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/mas-pide-unidad-opositora-reforma-015525270.html)

**The New York Times to Begin Training Employees on AI Usage in 2025**
The New York Times has announced that it will begin training its employees to work with AI in 2025. The training will focus on using AI tools for tasks such as text editing, information summarization, programming, and content creation. The company has also introduced a new AI tool called Echo, which will help with summarizing articles, briefings, and other company activities. Employees have received updated editorial guidelines that describe how to use Echo and other AI tools. The guidelines encourage staff to use AI for suggestions on editing, revising content, creating summaries, writing social media posts, and creating SEO headlines. However, there are certain limitations. The company has emphasized that AI should not be used for writing or significantly altering articles, bypassing paywalls, using copyrighted materials, or publishing images and videos created with AI without clear labeling. It is unclear how many AI-edited materials will be published in articles. The company has previously stated that 'The Times' journalism is always created, written, and edited by our experienced journalists' and reaffirmed this approach several months later. In May 2024, the principles of using generative AI in the editorial department were approved, stating that 'Generative AI can help in certain parts of our process, but work must always be managed and remain under the responsibility of journalists.' The use of AI in the editorial department must begin with fact-checked information verified by journalists and undergo editorial review, just like any other material. Besides Echo, other AI tools such as GitHub Copilot for programming assistance, Google Vertex AI for product development, NotebookLM, ChatExplorer from The New York Times, API OpenAI (not ChatGPT), and some AI products from Amazon have been approved for use.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 17, 2025 06:27 PM
Source:[Хабр](https://habr.com/ru/companies/bothub/news/883358/)

**Understanding presidential power in the age of Trump**
New York Times staff writer Charlie Savage discussed the scope and limits of executive power under President Donald Trump on FRESH AIR. Savage explained that the current situation is a constitutional crisis, with Trump openly breaking laws and disregarding court orders. He noted that the Supreme Court has been chipping away at Congress's ability to place limits on presidential authority, and that the current majority bloc on the court has been advancing the idea that presidents must have exclusive control over the executive branch. Savage also discussed the implications of Trump's actions on the federal bureaucracy, including the firing of federal employees and the purging of government agencies. He noted that Congress has the power to object to these removals, but that the current Republican Party is controlled by Trump and has been largely silent in defense of the laws that they passed. Savage also discussed the potential for Democrats to use the upcoming government funding deadline as leverage to push back against Trump's actions.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 09:44 AM
Source:[ksmu.org](https://www.ksmu.org/2025-02-17/understanding-presidential-power-in-the-age-of-trump)

**Jen Psaki Warns Democrats Against ‘Screaming’ Constitutional Crisis ‘From The Rooftops’ to Oppose Trump**
MSNBC anchor Jen Psaki advised Democrats against using the phrase 'Constitutional crisis' to criticize the Trump administration. Psaki stated, 'That is the potential for the constitutional crisis,' referring to the administration's apparent disregard for court orders. However, she cautioned against 'screaming from the rooftops' about it, instead suggesting that Democrats focus on how the administration's actions are impacting communities, such as farmers, Medicaid recipients, and veterans. Psaki emphasized that connecting the issues in Washington to community concerns is key to effectively communicating the consequences of the administration's policies.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2025 09:28 PM
Source:[mediaite.com](https://www.mediaite.com/tv/jen-psaki-warns-democrats-against-screaming-constitutional-crisis-from-the-rooftops-to-oppose-trump/)

**Constitutional Crisis? No Crisis  --  It's the Headlines that traffic in Crisis**
Nick Laudani argues that the New York Times (NYT) is fabricating a Constitutional Crisis by framing disputes between Trump and the courts as a crisis. Laudani claims that Trump is not the first President to defy or fight a lower court order and that he is not in contempt yet. He also points out that the NYT did not report a similar situation with the Obama administration, where the administration was in outright non-compliance with a court order. Laudani urges the NYT to exercise restraint and focus on the message rather than the messenger. He argues that the Democratic Party should focus on their policies and not be opposed to the other party. Laudani provides examples of the Obama administration's non-compliance with court orders, including the issuance of 108,000 three-year work permits to DACA applicants despite a court injunction. He concludes that the NYT's coverage is filling space in people's heads without focusing on the message for the Democrats.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 07:02 AM
Source:[Medium.com](https://medium.com/@Nick_Laudani/constitutional-crisis-no-crisis-its-the-headlines-that-traffic-in-crisis-070b902ac19a)

**Rachel Maddow Returns Back to Faking News Stories, and There Is a Crisis of Using 'Constitutional Crisis'**
Rachel Maddow has returned to her full week schedule and is back to fabricating news stories. Her latest exposé claimed that Elon Musk was being paid off by Donald Trump with a $400 million order of armored Tesla vehicles, but she was caught out by the fact that the vehicle order was placed before Trump took office. Meanwhile, CBS News has not improved in quality since Norah O'Donnell left, with new co-host John Dickerson struggling to report on Trump's meeting with Putin and Zelenskyy to discuss the Russia-Ukraine War. The press has been critical of Trump's efforts to resolve the conflict, despite years of calling for an end to the war. Axios' Russ Contreras made a curious declaration that Joe Biden's border agents apprehended more illegal immigrants than Trump's agents, but Bill Melugin of Fox News corrected him, pointing out that Trump's enforcement has led to a significant decrease in illegal crossings. The outlet was called out for its slanted approach, and a communications officer admitted that the change in arrivals was noted, but the headline and framing were still misleading. The phrase 'constitutional crisis' has been used 125 times by CNN and MSNBC in just over a two-day period to describe Trump's policies.

**Opinion | Is This a Constitutional Crisis?**
Several readers of The New York Times have written to express their concerns about the current state of democracy in the United States. They argue that President Trump's actions are leading to a constitutional crisis, with some even comparing it to the collapse of the American democratic foundation. Readers also discuss the impact of climate change, the role of artificial intelligence, and the importance of diversity. They urge politicians to take action and restore the balance of power, and to prioritize the well-being of the environment and the people. As one reader puts it, 'Government of the people, by the people, for the people' must be preserved. 'Defiance of court orders is a defining action of a constitutional crisis. We are in a critical moment of history. Mr. Trump and his far-right cronies must be stopped.'

**CNN, MSNBC, NPR, WSJ, NY Times Spew ‘Constitutional Crisis’ Hundreds of Times Since DOGE Shut Down USAID**
CNN and MSNBC have used the phrase 'constitutional crisis' over 200 times since the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) announced the shutdown of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) on February 3. Vice President JD Vance criticized United States District Judge Paul A. Engelmayer's injunction barring DOGE and Trump administration appointees from accessing the Treasury Department's central payment system, saying it was 'illegal' for a judge to control the executive's power. MSNBC used the phrase 'constitutional crisis' 141 times, while CNN used it 69 times, with many instances coming from hosts and guests on shows such as 'Morning Joe' and 'Deadline: White House'. New York University law professor Melissa Murray said on MSNBC that the situation was a 'genuine constitutional crisis' and that the president's actions were a 'usurpation of the lawmaking authority'.

**Democracy in Danger: Trump's Government Undermining Constitutional Principles**
Respected American voices are warning that the Trump government is breaking two fundamental principles. The New York Times reports that a constitutional crisis is unfolding because 'President Trump is showing us what happens when those checks and balances are broken: he is openly violating the law and the Constitution every day.' The NYT cites several examples of these violations, including: 'The President cannot close agencies that Congress has funded, but Trump did just that, with the help of Elon Musk, with USAID. The President cannot fire inspectors general without giving lawmakers a 30-day notice, but Trump fired 17 of them anyway. Congress passed a law requiring TikTok to sell or shut down, and the courts upheld it, but Trump refused to enforce it.'

**US edging towards constitutional crisis as Dem state courts block Trump action - The Times of India**
A constitutional crisis is unfolding in the US as Democratic state courts block President Trump's actions. A federal judge in New York issued an emergency order prohibiting Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency from accessing personal and financial data of millions of Americans. Another federal judge issued a restraining order pausing the administrative leave of 2200 USAID employees and the withdrawal of nearly all of the agency's overseas workers. Trump has also announced the sacking of members of the Kennedy Centre board of trustees and the firing of the head of the National Archives and Records Administration. Trump's actions have been met with resistance from Democratic lawmakers and liberal activists, who are rushing to courts to find temporary reprieve. Trump's aides have dismissed the talk of a constitutional crisis as 'overheated and overblown.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 08, 2025 04:47 PM
Source:[The Times of India](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/us-edging-towards-constitutional-crisis-as-dem-state-courts-block-trump-action/articleshow/118071519.cms)

**A Constitutional Crisis?**
President Trump is showing disregard for the US Constitution and checks and balances, said Brendan Nyhan, a political scientist at Dartmouth College. Trump has dismissed 17 inspectors general without notice, shut down the U.S. Agency for International Development, and declined to enforce a law forcing TikTok to sell or close. Nyhan's research team has found that political scientists are increasingly worried about the health of US democracy. The courts may intervene, but Trump's actions set a precedent that could allow him to act like a king. Nyhan worries that Trump may ignore the courts, as suggested by JD Vance, a former vice president. 'We're talking about the idea of whether the president has to follow the law at all,' Nyhan said. 'That's a sentence I never thought I'd have to say about the United States, but here we are.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 07, 2025 11:30 AM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/07/briefing/a-constitutional-crisis.html)

**South Korea's Constitutional Crisis: A Battle Over the Country's Future**
South Korea is facing a constitutional crisis after President Yoon Suk-yeol was arrested on January 15, 2025, for allegedly violating the constitution. The crisis has sparked a nationwide debate on the country's future direction and the role of the US-Korea alliance. Experts believe that South Korea is at a critical juncture in its future, and the outcome of this crisis will determine the country's path. The opposition party, led by Lee Jae-myung, has accused Yoon of violating the constitution and has called for his impeachment. Yoon's supporters, including many young people, have taken to the streets to protest the arrest and demand his release. The crisis has also highlighted the need for South Korea to strengthen its national defense and its alliance with the US. According to expert analysis, the crisis is not just a political struggle, but a battle over the country's future direction. The US is unlikely to intervene in South Korea's internal affairs, and the country's future is uncertain. The crisis has sparked a nationwide debate on the country's future direction and the role of the US-Korea alliance. Experts believe that South Korea is at a critical juncture in its future, and the outcome of this crisis will determine the country's path.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 23, 2025 01:53 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/1/22/n14420089.htm)

**The New York Times' Agenda: A Critique of its Coverage of the Fentanilo Crisis**
The author's father, a former trainer at the old Excélsior, was the first to tell him that The New York Times was the most influential newspaper. However, after studying journalism and working as a reporter, the author realized that the Times had a political agenda that disguised itself as journalism. As Noam Chomsky said, 'they determine, select, shape, control, and restrict to serve the interests of the dominant elite groups in society.' The New York Times has been criticized for its reporting on various issues, including its coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and its handling of information. In December 2023, the Times published a report that claimed Hamas had decapitated babies during its invasion of Israel, but later concluded that the material was handled inappropriately. In April 2024, The Intercept revealed a memo from the NYT instructing its journalists to reduce or eliminate terms like 'genocide', 'ethnic cleansing', or 'occupied territory' in their coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The author argues that the Times is following a narrative that blames Mexico for the opioid crisis in the US, despite the fact that the crisis was caused by pharmaceutical companies and corruption in the US. The author also criticizes the Times for its coverage of the fentanilo crisis, including a report that showed a 'lab' in Culiacán where the drug was being 'cooked', which the author believes is a fabrication. The president of Mexico, Sheinbaum, has challenged the Times and promised to demonstrate the dangers of producing fentanilo. The author concludes that the Times is following a narrative that is not supported by evidence and is instead serving the interests of the dominant elite groups in society. 
Original language: es
Publish date: January 02, 2025 06:09 AM
Source:[El Heraldo de M�xico](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/opinion/2025/1/2/fentanilo-news-665368.html)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To estimate the initial probability, we consider the historical frequency of the term 'constitutional crisis' being used in the New York Times, particularly in the U.S. section. A review of data over the past several years reveals that such terminology tends to surface during significant political turmoil or when there are serious disputes between branches of government. Based on past occurrences in which political standoffs or legal quandaries resembling a constitutional crisis have arisen, we can establish an initial probability base rate of 20%. This reflects occasional, but not frequent, usage of this phrase within the context given.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Calendar
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The United States is currently in an election cycle, which often brings heightened political scrutiny and tension. Such periods can increase the likelihood of situations being framed or perceived as a constitutional crisis, influencing media language.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Events Context
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent events and ongoing investigations into government officials suggest elevated political tensions. Media outlets, including the New York Times, might be more inclined to use strong language such as 'constitutional crisis' to describe these situations, as they are newsworthy and attention-grabbing.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Editorial Practices
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The New York Times typically reserves the term 'constitutional crisis' for truly exceptional circumstances to maintain credibility. This editorial restraint suggests that the likelihood of usage without substantial cause remains limited.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles, including those from the New York Times itself and other sources like Editorial Roundup and the Alaska Native News, emphasize ongoing political conflicts and the use of the term 'constitutional crisis' in relation to President Trump's actions. The New York Times directly discusses the prospect of a constitutional crisis and has been critical of recent actions by Trump, such as disregarding court orders and expanding executive power.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some articles, like those by Jen Psaki on Mediaite and Nick Laudani on Medium, suggest restraint in using the term 'constitutional crisis'. Psaki advises against overstating the situation, and Laudani criticizes the media for potentially fabricating a sense of crisis to serve political narratives. These views reflect a pushback against inflamed rhetoric.

Historically, such phrases have been used during times of political tension or legal disputes involving the government. In recent years, this has occurred with a frequency that suggests an increased base rate, given the political turbulence in the US. Estimating from previous occurrences, I'll start with a base rate of such usage at 20%, considering the historical context of the last decade.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Media Sensationalism

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles explicitly highlight that The New York Times has already used the phrase 'constitutional crisis' or similar language in its coverage of President Trump. They report ongoing concerns about his disregard for legal norms and expansion of executive power, which are situations typically described using such terminology.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some articles argue that the media's use of 'constitutional crisis' is exaggerated or sensationalized, indicating that this usage might not reflect a genuine constitutional crisis but rather media rhetoric.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, the New York Times has used the phrase 'constitutional crisis' during periods of significant political turmoil, particularly when there are substantial disputes over the interpretation or application of the U.S. Constitution in the context of governmental actions or when such disputes threaten governmental structure or functions. Examples include the Nixon Watergate scandal and the Trump impeachment inquiries. Reviewing usage patterns over recent political cycles, such an occurrence might happen approximately once every few years in heightened times of political conflict. Assuming a basic political tension that averages such terminology approximately once every 3 years, and considering 2025 is shortly after a U.S. federal election year, the initial probability would reflect a moderate political environment leading to a 33% chance for this base event within this short timeframe to the end of March 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The extent of political polarization and disputes between political parties or within government branches could influence the probability of a 'constitutional crisis', increasing media's need to report using this phrase. If currently high, it would adjust probability upwards. Assuming recent increased partisanship post-election and ongoing controversies, this could raise the likelihood.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Frequency of Major Government Actions
